source.e6df8f27:
duration = []
for x in collection0.find():
    duration.append(int(x['duree']))
print("Mean value of a trip duration:")
print(np.mean(duration))
print("Median value of a trip duration:")
print(np.median(duration))
print("Variance of a trip duration:")
print(np.var(duration))
print("Standard deviation of a trip duration:")
print(np.std(duration))
print("Maximum duration of a trip:")
print(np.max(duration))
print("Minimum duration of a trip:")
print(np.min(duration))

count =0
for x in collection0.find():
    if (x['duree']=='NA'):
      count=count+1
    
print("Number of null or NA values: " + str(count))

source.8e924981:
import collections
var = []
sex = []
var1 = []
var2 = []

for x in collection3.find():
    var.append((x['permis']))
    sex.append(int(x['sexe']))
    
for i in range(0, len(sex)): 
    if(sex[i] == 1):
        var1.append(var[i])
    else:
        var2.append(var[i]) 

occur1 = {}
occur2 = {}
occur1 = dict(collections.Counter(var1))
occur1 = dict(collections.OrderedDict(sorted(occur1.items())))
print("sex = 1, driving licence: ", occur1)
occur2 = dict(collections.Counter(var2))
occur2 = dict(collections.OrderedDict(sorted(occur2.items())))
print("sex = 2, driving licence: ", occur2)

# Plot

plt.figure()
plt.subplot(121)
plt.pie(list(occur1.values()),autopct='%1.1f%%', shadow=True, startangle=140, radius = 1.5, colors = ['#ff9999','#66b3ff','#99ff99','#ffcc99'])
plt.legend(title = "Driving licence", labels=list(occur1.keys()),bbox_to_anchor=(1.5,0),loc="lower right")
plt.title("Sex = 1", y=1.10)

plt.subplot(122)
plt.pie(list(occur2.values()),autopct='%1.1f%%', shadow=True, startangle=140, radius = 1.5, colors = ['#ff9999','#66b3ff','#99ff99','#ffcc99'])
plt.title("Sex = 2", y=1.10)
plt.tight_layout()

plt.show()
source.f3c71976:
import matplotlib.patches as mpatches
var = []
sex = []
var1 = []
var2 = []

for x in collection3.find():
    var.append((x['OCCU1']))
    sex.append(int(x['sexe']))
    
for i in range(0, len(sex)): 
    if(sex[i] == 1):
        var1.append(var[i])
    else:
        var2.append(var[i]) 

occur1 = {}
occur2 = {}
occur1 = dict(collections.Counter(var1))
occur1 = dict(collections.OrderedDict(sorted(occur1.items())))
print("sex = 1, occupation: ", occur1)
occur2 = dict(collections.Counter(var2))
occur2 = dict(collections.OrderedDict(sorted(occur2.items())))
print("sex = 2, occupation: ", occur2)

# Plot

#plt.figure()
#plt.subplot(121)
#plt.bar(range(len(occur1)), list(occur1.values()), align='center')
#plt.xticks(range(len(occur1)), list(occur1.keys()))

#plt.subplot(122)
#plt.bar(range(len(occur2)), list(occur2.values()), align='center')
#plt.xticks(range(len(occur2)), list(occur2.keys()))
#plt.tight_layout()

x1 = list(occur1.keys())
y1 = list(occur1.values())
x2 = list(occur2.keys())
y2 = list(occur2.values())
plt.plot(x1, y1, 'g')
plt.plot(x2, y2, 'r')
plt.xlabel("Occupation")
plt.ylabel("Number of people")
green_patch = mpatches.Patch(color='green', label='Sex = 1')
red_patch = mpatches.Patch(color='red', label='Sex = 2')
plt.legend(handles=[green_patch,red_patch])
plt.show()

source.2c72cf97:
occur1= {}
var1 = []
for x in collection3.find():
    var1.append((x['freqtram']))
occur1 = dict(collections.Counter(var1))
occur1 = dict(collections.OrderedDict(sorted(occur1.items())))

occur2= {}
var2 = []
for x in collection3.find():
    var2.append((x['fqvelo']))
occur2 = dict(collections.Counter(var2))
occur2 = dict(collections.OrderedDict(sorted(occur2.items())))

occur3= {}
var3 = []
for x in collection3.find():
    var3.append((x['fqvpcond']))
occur3 = dict(collections.Counter(var3))
occur3 = dict(collections.OrderedDict(sorted(occur3.items())))

# Plot
barWidth = 0.25

r1 = np.arange(len(occur1))
r2 = [x + barWidth for x in r1]
r3 = [x + barWidth for x in r2]

plt.bar(r1, list(occur1.values()), color='purple', width=barWidth, edgecolor='white', label='tram')
plt.bar(r2, list(occur2.values()), color='salmon', width=barWidth, edgecolor='white', label='velo')
plt.bar(r3, list(occur3.values()), color='aquamarine', width=barWidth, edgecolor='white', label='var3')

plt.xticks([r + barWidth for r in range(len(occur1))], list(occur1.keys()))
plt.xlabel("Frequency of transport usage among all the population")
plt.ylabel("Number of people")

patch1 = mpatches.Patch(color='purple', label='Tram')
patch2 = mpatches.Patch(color='salmon', label='Bicycle')
patch3 = mpatches.Patch(color='aquamarine', label='Car - driver')
plt.legend(handles=[patch1, patch2, patch3])

plt.show()

source.20fb30c0: The conclusion is that more someone travels, shorter the trips are. On the opposite, if a person travels rarely, it is more probable that his trip will be longer than the mean duration. This can be explained by the fact that people who need to take a transport to go to their work will be traveling frequently and they will not spend a lot of time in the transport. On the other hand, if a person goes to work by foot, this person will take a transport for a special occasions and longer distances.

source.9d3cac64: For sharding using intervals we can use attribute 'zoneres'. The first interval is zone #1 - 20735 obj., second interval is zone #2 - 17799 obj., third interval is zone #3-59 - 24802 obj. Interval-based partitioning supports more efficient range queries. However, it can result in an uneven distribution of data.
source.e33cfaf5: We would like to shard the first collection as it is the biggest one. In this collections there are 63336 objects, so if we want to have 3 shards, each one will have approximately 21112 object.
source.b90fe1ff: The main occupations with the oldest ages are number 7 and 8 according to the graph. As the interpretation of different values of occupation is not given, we can try to make our own assumptions. After a discussion with the group members, we can relate the occupation number 5 with pupils and students (from 5 to 25 years approximately) and the occupation number 7 to retired (from 50 to 100 years old approximately) according to the age rank visualised on the graph. Besides, we can state that the youngest age for the other occupations is around 18 years old.
source.18f3a039: We can notice that the most popular transport is tram. Afterwards, people prefer to take a bicycle. The frequency of car usage is quite even, approximately the same number of people are taking a car for a frequency #2,4 and 5.
